terms.definition: A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or files over time, allowing users to see revision history and ensure everyone works with the latest version.
A chronological record of all changes, access, and activities performed on documents or systems, essential for compliance and accountability.
A single, unified location where all organizational documents and files are stored and managed, accessible to authorized users.
The ability for multiple users to work on the same document simultaneously, with changes visible instantly to all participants.
Pre-configured sequences of tasks and processes that execute automatically based on triggers or conditions, reducing manual intervention.
Security measures that determine which users can view, edit, or manage specific documents or system features based on their roles and permissions.
The systematic organization, storage, tracking, and control of electronic documents throughout their lifecycle.
Formal records and documents required to demonstrate adherence to regulatory standards, laws, and industry requirements.
Enterprise Resource Planning - integrated software systems that manage and automate core business processes across an organization.
Product Lifecycle Management - software systems that manage product data and processes throughout a product's entire lifecycle from conception to disposal.
Groups of people from different departments or specialties working together toward a common goal, requiring shared documentation and communication.
A technology-based system or environment that enables users to create, manage, and share digital content and services.
The process of connecting different software systems and applications to work together and share data seamlessly.
Pre-formatted document structures that provide consistent layouts and required fields for specific types of documentation.
Software as a Service - cloud-based software applications delivered over the internet on a subscription basis rather than installed locally.
